2.1.01-001.info: Defective shock absorbers can adversely affect the inclination of the vehicle and thus impair driving stability. This may cause skidding on bends. If the tyre pressure is too low or varies, this has an unfavourable effect on road grip and driving stability.
2.1.01-001.text: What can cause skidding on bends?

2.1.01-004.asw_3: Driving too far behind the vehicle in front
2.1.01-004.info: Cutting corners is dangerous because there is a risk of collision with oncoming traffic. Late dimming may dazzle oncoming traffic, which may cross the lane or leave the lane.
2.1.01-004.text: What can cause a dangerous situation?

2.1.01-102.asw_1: Blind people lose their orientation when they are near the car
2.1.01-102.asw_2: The driver’s attention is significantly impaired
2.1.01-102.asw_3: It makes it easier for blind people to recognise where the road is
2.1.01-102.info: Listening to loud music is a distraction that affects the driver's attention. Blind pedestrians can be disturbed in their orientation by the loud music.
2.1.01-102.text: What are the effects of listening to loud music - especially with an extremely loud bass volume - in the car?

2.1.03-015.info: Worn tyres have poor water displacement, which in turn can cause aquaplaning. Water accumulates in ruts, which increases the danger. The higher the speed, the worse the water is drained through the treads.
2.1.03-015.text: What can cause in aquaplaning (sliding on wet roads) on wet road surfaces?

2.1.03-017-B.asw_1: There is still slush on the overtaking lane
2.1.03-017-B.asw_2: Slush could be thrown up and impair visibility
2.1.03-017-B.asw_3: Because beneath the slush there could also be ice on the road
2.1.03-017-B.info: The overtaking lane is covered with slush, which can severely impair road grip. In addition, there is the danger that the road under the slush may still be icy. The vehicles to be overtaken can splash slush and water, which impairs visibility.
2.1.03-017-B.text: Why could overtaking be dangerous here?

2.1.03-018.info: In strong crosswinds, counter-steering helps to keep the vehicle on track. A reduction in speed helps to keep the vehicle under control despite strong side winds.
2.1.03-018.text: What must you do if your vehicle is caught by a strong side wind?

2.1.03-021-B.asw_1: Your vehicle could be blown to the left by the strong side wind
2.1.03-021-B.asw_2: When overtaking, your vehicle is pulling to the right when you enter the slipstream of the truck
2.1.03-021-B.asw_3: The vehicle travelling in front of you can be blown to the right
2.1.03-021-B.info: The wind vane signals a side wind from the right, so your car is pushed to the left. When driving into the slipstream of the truck, the crosswind no longer acts so strongly pulling the car to the right.
2.1.03-021-B.text: What must you reckon with here?

2.1.03-023.asw_3: Because aquaplaning (sliding on wet roads) can occur
2.1.03-023.info: Heavy rainfall impairs visibility and thus requires speed adjustment. At the same time, aquaplaning is a risk. The braking distance is extended by heavy moisture.
2.1.03-023.text: Why must you reduce your speed in heavy rain?

2.1.03-025.info: A deterioration in the condition of the road surface may result in skidding or slipping, e.g., due to potholes or reduced traction caused by the road surface. A bad road often causes tyres to produce loud noises.
2.1.03-025.text: What can be caused if the road surface suddenly becomes worse?

2.1.03-027.asw_1: Bends are often very narrow and blind
2.1.03-027.asw_2: The narrow and often cambered roadway requires special caution when there is oncoming traffic
2.1.03-027.asw_3: The trees provide protection from the sides
2.1.03-027.info: Rows of trees are a characteristic of avenues. These often result in tight bends and can impair visibility. The carriageway may be narrow and curved, which requires increased caution, especially in the case of oncoming traffic.
2.1.03-027.text: What are the special conditions when driving along tree-lined avenues?

2.1.03-101.asw_2: Where there are grooves in the roadway
2.1.03-101.info: Water can collect in dips in the roadway, which can cause aquaplaning.
2.1.03-101.text: Where does aquaplaning (sliding on wet roads) occur particularly often?

2.1.03-103.asw_1: A dangerous greasy film on the surface of the road
2.1.03-103.asw_2: Bad visibility immediately upon switching the windscreen wipers on
2.1.03-103.info: Dust and other dirt particles on the windshield can form a greasy film, making visibility difficult. A similar film can also form on the road surface, which can lead to deterioration in grip.
2.1.03-103.text: What must you reckon with when it starts raining after a long period of dry weather?

2.1.03-104.asw_1: Because a greasy film may form which increases the braking distance
2.1.03-104.asw_2: Because visibility may become worse and the windscreen wipers do not immediately provide a clear field of vision
2.1.03-104.asw_3: Because the brakes react more quickly
2.1.03-104.info: In the case of rain, a lubricating film can form on the road surface, which worsens the road grip. Dust and other dirt particles on the windshield can form a greasy film, making visibility difficult.
2.1.03-104.text: It starts raining. Why must you immediately increase the safe distance?

2.1.03-105.asw_1: No, because it could represent a danger to oncoming traffic
2.1.03-105.asw_2: Yes, if fog headlamps and rear fog lamps are switched on
2.1.03-105.asw_3: Yes, because it reduces the risk of running off the road
2.1.03-105.info: Crossing the middle line may reduce the risk of getting off the road, but it increases the risk of collision with oncoming traffic. Therefore, it is not allowed to use the roadway in this manner.
2.1.03-105.text: You are driving in dense fog on a federal road (Bundesstraße) outside a built-up area. Are you allowed to drive in the middle of the road continuously straddling the broken white line?

2.1.03-106.asw_1: Adapt speed immediately to visibility conditions
2.1.03-106.info: Your speed should be adapted in particular to road, traffic, visibility and weather conditions as well as to the personal abilities and characteristics of the vehicle and load. If visibility due to fog, snow or rain is less than 50 m, the speed must not exceed 50 km/h unless a lower speed is required. If fog suddenly appears and visibility deteriorates your speed must thus be adapted immediately to the new visibility conditions. Switching on the dipped beam is necessary in order to be seen more easily by other motorists.
2.1.03-106.text: What must you do on encountering sudden dense fog driving at daytime?

2.1.03-107.asw_1: Switch on the windscreen wipers from time to time when it is foggy
2.1.03-107.asw_2: When there is slush, switch on the windscreen wipers already before slush is thrown onto your windscreen by other vehicles
2.1.03-107.asw_3: When the windscreen is steamed up, switch the ventilator off and keep the windows closed
2.1.03-107.info: Over time, small drops of fog may accumulate on the windscreen and affect visibility. Using the windscreen wipers as required helps to maintain good visibility. Trucks in particular can splash large quantities of slush onto the windscreen, which immediately restricts the visibility of the road and traffic. Switching on the windscreen wipers beforehand prevents this risk.
2.1.03-107.text: How can you achieve sufficient visibility through the windscreen?

2.1.04-002.info: If wild animals are dazzled by full beam, they often stop in the beam of light. Therefore, the high beams must be turned off immediately. Additional honking of the horn can draw the animal's attention to the approaching danger. In addition, the brakes must be applied to prevent a collision.
2.1.04-002.text: What must you do if wild animals suddenly appear in the full beam of your headlights?

2.1.04-102.asw_1: You can be dazzled by reflections on the wet road
2.1.04-102.asw_2: Your wet windscreen can result in your being dazzled
2.1.04-102.asw_3: You can avoid possible dazzle by switching on full beam
2.1.04-102.info: In the dark, a wet road can intensify the effect dazzing headlights. In addition, streaks on the windscreen are more visible in the dark and can significantly impair visibility.
2.1.04-102.text: You are driving on a country road in darkness and rain and encounter oncoming vehicles with dipped headlights. What must you remember?

2.1.05-001.asw_1: You lose your feel for speed
2.1.05-001.asw_3: The feel for the right speed on bends grows
2.1.05-001.info: When driving at high speed for a longer period of time, the perception changes and motorists often underestimate the speed. Since fast driving requires a high degree of concentration, the ability to concentrate decreases over time.
2.1.05-001.text: You have been driving at high speed for some time. What effects can this have?

2.1.05-002.asw_1: You lose your feel for speed
2.1.05-002.asw_2: You drive too close to vehicles in front
2.1.05-002.info: When driving at high speed for a longer period of time, the perception changes and motorists often underestimate the speed. Due to the influenced perception, motorists tend to drive close to the vehicles in front of them.
2.1.05-002.text: What can result from driving for a long time at high speed?

2.1.05-005.asw_1: Driving for a long time at high speed
2.1.05-005.asw_2: Driving on a good, wide road
2.1.05-005.info: When the road is wide and well developed, speed is often considered to be too low. Prolonged driving at high speed has a similar effect.
2.1.05-005.text: What can lead to your dangerously underestimating your own speed?

2.1.05-101.asw_1: To estimate the lateral distance to the trees and oncoming traffic simultaneously
2.1.05-101.asw_2: It may be necessary to stop within half the visible distance when a wide vehicle is coming from the opposite direction
2.1.05-101.asw_3: Rapidly changing light conditions make it easier to estimate lateral distances
2.1.05-101.info: Avenues are bordered by trees and often have a narrow lane. This makes it all the more important to consider the lateral distance twice, i.e., to oncoming traffic and trees. If an oncoming vehicle is very wide, it may be necessary for your vehicle to stop in order for both vehicles to drive past each other safely.
2.1.05-101.text: What is especially important when choosing the speed for driving along tree-lined avenues with narrow roadways?

2.1.06-002.asw_1: Because you must reckon with others in the queue swinging out to overtake
2.1.06-002.asw_2: Because the distance needed to overtake might not be sufficient
2.1.06-002.asw_3: Because if you perhaps need to push back into the queue, this could lead to an accident
2.1.06-002.info: The last person in a convoy to overtake has to cover the longest overtaking distance and is thus in the lane of oncoming traffic for a particularly long time. At the same time, it is to be expected that other motorists will also leave the convoy. If it should be necessary to merge back into the original lane, an accident could occur.
2.1.06-002.text: Why can it be dangerous if you, as the last in a queue, immediately overtake as soon as the oncoming traffic is past?

2.1.06-004-B.asw_1: No, because there is no queue of vehicles in the left lane
2.1.06-004-B.asw_2: Yes, if you do not drive faster than 80 km/h
2.1.06-004-B.asw_3: Yes, because there is enough space to overtake
2.1.06-004-B.info: Vehicles must overtake on the left. There is no reason to overtake from the right, especially as there is no queue on the left.
2.1.06-004-B.text: Are you allowed to overtake the black car on this autobahn on the right?

2.1.06-005-B.asw_1: - the distance you need to overtake would be too great
2.1.06-005-B.asw_2: - the light-coloured car could pull out to overtake
2.1.06-005-B.asw_3: - you are not allowed to cross the broken line
2.1.06-005-B.info: The overtaking distance to the bend is short, which makes overtaking too dangerous. In addition, the light-coloured car could pull out to overtake.
2.1.06-005-B.text: Both cars are travelling at about 30 km/h. Are you allowed to overtake both before the bend?

2.1.07-006-B.asw_1: Watch if the truck and trailer remain on the hard shoulder
2.1.07-006-B.asw_2: Allow the truck and trailer to enter the roadway when it indicates left
2.1.07-006-B.asw_3: When the truck and trailer are indicating left, flash your headlights and proceed at a brisk pace
2.1.07-006-B.info: It is not yet clear whether the tractor will remain on the side strip. That's why it's important to keep an eye on the tractor. If the driver of the tractor signals a turn, he must be able to make the change.
2.1.07-006-B.text: You are approaching the vehicles in this picture. What do you do?

2.1.07-101.asw_1: It is suddenly hit by a gust of strong side wind
2.1.07-101.info: Veering sideways is also possible on dry roads. A strong crosswind that suddenly occuring can cause this. If a tyre bursts, the driving stability is impaired and the vehicle can also veer sideways.
2.1.07-101.text: What could cause a fast travelling motor vehicle suddenly to veer sideways on a dry straight road?

2.1.07-102.asw_1: Watching the queue through the windows of the vehicles travelling in front
2.1.07-102.asw_2: Driving in a slightly staggered position in your own lane
2.1.07-102.asw_3: Keeping your hazard warning lights switched on when driving
2.1.07-102.info: Driving in a slightly staggered position within one's own lane helps to better understand the traffic situation and, for example, recognize dangerous situations earlier. The view through the windows of the preceding vehicles can be similarly useful.
2.1.07-102.text: What makes driving in a stream of vehicles easier?

2.1.07-106.asw_1: Throttle down, if necessary, steer against and brake cautiously
2.1.07-106.asw_2: Stop, if possible, on the hard shoulder, switch on hazard warning lights and place the warning triangle
2.1.07-106.asw_3: Immediately apply the brakes fully and move over onto the hard shoulder
2.1.07-106.info: The first step is to keep the vehicle under control and bring it slowly but surely to a standstill. If possible, do not stop on the roadway; rather, stop on the hard shoulder of the road.
2.1.07-106.text: One of your tyres bursts while you are travelling at high speed on an autobahn. What do you do?

2.1.08-005-B.asw_1: The vehicle in front changing lanes
2.1.08-005-B.asw_3: The right-hand lane coming to an end
2.1.08-005-B.info: The left lane ends. Therefore, the car in front will change to the right lane. The merging of both lanes results in a densification of traffic.
2.1.08-005-B.text: What must you reckon with here?

2.1.08-008-B.asw_1: If possible, switch on hazard warning lights to warn vehicles following behind
2.1.08-008-B.asw_2: Drive as far as possible to the right in order to leave room for a channel on the left
2.1.08-008-B.asw_3: Drive as far as possible to the left in order to leave room for a channel on the right
2.1.08-008-B.info: By switching on the hazard warning light, other motorists are warned earlier, which reduces the risk of accidents. If the traffic on motorways and extra-urban roads is congested with at least two lanes for one direction, vehicles must form a free lane in the middle of the directional lane for the passage of police and auxiliary vehicles. In the case of lanes with three lanes for one direction, this free lane must be formed between the left lane and the middle lane.
2.1.08-008-B.text: A traffic jam is building up here. What is the correct procedure?

2.1.10-002.asw_1: By well-timed and sufficient stops for rests
2.1.10-002.asw_3: Drink coffee and make no stops
2.1.10-002.info: In the case of fatigue, only recovery helps. The body must be given an appropriately long break. Gymnastic exercises help to stimulate the circulation and activate the body as a whole.
2.1.10-002.text: How can fatigue be prevented on a long journey?

2.1.10-101.asw_3: Engrossing programs on the car radio
2.1.10-101.info: Lively conversations – with passengers or on the telephone – attract attention and can contribute to the fact that insufficient attention is paid to road traffic. The same applies to listening to exciting programmes on the car radio or driving when impacted by strong emotions.
2.1.10-101.text: What can diminish alertness in road traffic?

2.1.10-102.info: Lighting a cigarette while driving requires more attention than is generally assumed. For this reason, it is a major distraction. Children whining can significantly reduce the driver's concentration, as can making a phone call while behind the wheel.
2.1.10-102.text: What strongly distracts you while you are driving?

2.2.02-006.info: If, outside of built-up areas, three or more lanes are signposted for one direction by a guideline, motor vehicles may, in deviation from the requirement to drive as far to the right as possible, drive continuously on the central lane if – even occasionally – a vehicle stops or drives to the right of it. Therefore, the use of the middle lane is permitted in this case.
2.2.02-006.text: You are driving on a road outside a built-up area with three lanes marked in each direction. Individual slower vehicles are travelling well spaced out in the right-hand lane. Which lane may you use continuously?

2.2.03-006.info: The stopping distance consists of the reaction distance + braking distance. Reaction distance in m = Speed in km/h / 10 x 3 Braking distance in m according to the rule of thumb = Speed in km/h / 10 x Speed in km/h / 10 Reaction distance of the task = 100 / 10 x 3 = 30 m Braking distance of the task = 100 / 10 x 100 / 10 = 100 m Reaction distance + braking distance = 30 + 100 = 130 m
2.2.03-006.text: You are travelling at 100 km/h, have a reaction time of 1 second, and brake normally. What is the stopping distance according to the rule of thumb?

2.2.03-007.info: The braking distance in m according to the rule of thumb is as follows: speed in km/h / 10 x speed in km/h / 10 braking distance of the task = 100 / 10 x 100 / 10 = 100 m
2.2.03-007.text: You are travelling at 100 km/h and brake normally. What is the braking distance according to the rule of thumb?

2.2.03-008.info: The reaction distance is the distance covered by the vehicle from the detection of the danger to the initiation of braking. The reaction distance according to rule of thumb is as follows: speed in km/h / 10 x 3 Reaction distance of the task = 100 / 10 x 3 = 30 m
2.2.03-008.text: You are travelling at 100 km/h and have a reaction time of 1 second. What is the reaction distance according to the rule of thumb?

2.2.03-009.info: The stopping distance consists of the reaction distance + braking distance. The rule of thumb is as follows: Reaction distance in m = Speed in km/h / 10 x 3 Braking distance in m according to rule of thumb = Speed in km/h / 10 x Speed in km/h / 10 Reaction distance of task = 50 / 10 x 3 = 15 m Braking distance of task = 50 / 10 x 50 / 10 = 25 m Reaction distance + Braking distance = 15 + 25 = 40 m
2.2.03-009.text: You are travelling at 50 km/h, have a reaction time of 1 second, and brake normally. What is the stopping distance according to the rule of thumb?

2.2.03-010.info: The braking distance in m according to the rule of thumb is as follows: speed in km/h / 10 x speed in km/h / 10 braking distance of the task = 50 / 10 x 50 / 10 = 25 m
2.2.03-010.text: You are travelling at 50 km/h and brake normally. What is the braking distance according to the rule of thumb?

2.2.03-011.info: Reaction distance in m = Speed in km/h / 10 x 3 Reaction distance of the task = 50 / 10 x 3 = 15 m
2.2.03-011.text: You are travelling at 50 km/h and have a reaction time of 1 second. What is the reaction distance according to the rule of thumb?

2.2.03-012.info: On lanes that are so narrow that oncoming vehicles could be endangered, you must drive slow enough to stop at least within half of the visible distance. Therefore, the stopping distance must not exceed 25 m when viewed from a distance of 50 m.
2.2.03-012.text: You are driving on a very narrow road and can see 50 m ahead. What must be your maximum stopping distance?

2.2.03-015.info:
In the event of a dangerous braking manoeuvre, braking is more violent, which is why the braking distance is shorter.

The rule of thumb for braking distance in m is as follows: speed in km/h / 10 x speed in km/h / 10

With hazard braking the braking distance is halved. Therefore, the following applies:

(speed in km/h / 10 x speed in km/h / 10) / 2
2.2.03-015.text: What is the rule of thumb when calculating the braking distance for evasive braking on a dry, even and asphalted roadway?

2.2.03-016.info:
In the event of a dangerous braking manoeuvre, brakes will be used in a more violent manner, which is why the braking distance is shorter.

Braking distance in m according to the rule of thumb is as follows:

speed in km/h / 10 x speed in km/h / 10

The braking distance is halved in the event of dangerous braking.

Braking distance of the task =

(50 / 10 x 50 / 10) / 2 = 12.5 m
2.2.03-016.text: You are travelling at 40 km/h. The braking distance for evasive braking is approximately 8 metres. How long is the braking distance at 50 km/h given otherwise the same conditions?

2.2.03-101.info: The maximum authorised speed for motor vehicles equipped with snow chains is 50 km/h, even under the most favourable conditions. Regardless of the type of vehicle, you must not drive faster.
2.2.03-101.text: What is the maximum speed a motor vehicle fitted with snow chains is allowed to travel?

2.2.03-104.info: Even under the most favourable conditions, the maximum authorised speed is 100 km/h for passenger cars and other motor vehicles with a maximum authorised mass not exceeding 3.5 tonnes.
2.2.03-104.text: What is the maximum speed you are allowed to drive a car on roads with one marked lane for each direction outside built-up areas?

2.2.03-105.info: Even under the most favourable conditions, the maximum authorised speed is 100 km/h for passenger cars and other motor vehicles with a maximum authorised mass not exceeding 3.5 tonnes.
2.2.03-105.text: What is the maximum speed you are allowed to drive a truck with a permissible total mass of 3.0 t on roads with one marked lane for each direction outside built-up areas?

2.2.03-106.info: Even under the most favourable conditions outside built-up areas, the maximum authorised speed is 80 km/h for lorries and motor caravans up to a maximum authorised mass of 3.5 tonnes with trailer.
2.2.03-106.text: What is the maximum speed a truck with a permissible total mass of 3.0 t and trailer may be driven on autobahns?

2.2.04-001.info: The minimum distance cannot only be derived from the speedometer. Alternatively, outside built-up areas, the two-second interval is applicable. Two seconds are counted. The point at which the vehicle in front was at the beginning of the time determination may not be reached after two seconds at the earliest.
2.2.04-001.text: You are driving at 80 km/h behind a motor vehicle. What is the minimum safe distance you must observe?

2.2.04-002.info: In built-up areas, the safety distance should be at least 15 metres or approx. three car lengths.
2.2.04-002.text: You are driving in urban traffic on a dry roadway in a stream of traffic travelling at a speed of 50 km/h. What is the minimum safe distance you must keep from the vehicle in front?

2.2.04-003.info: Outside built-up areas, the safety distance should be at least half the speed of the automobile as shown on the speedometer.
2.2.04-003.text: What is the minimum distance that should normally be maintained from the vehicle in front outside built-up areas?

2.2.04-102.asw_pretext: Answer: When the combination of vehicles exceeds
2.2.04-102.info: Any automobile and trailer combination that exceeds 7.00 m (the combined length of the car and trailer) driving outside of built-up areas must always keep a sufficient distance from the vehicle in front of it so that an overtaking vehicle can merge.
2.2.04-102.text: When must a car with trailer driving outside built-up areas on roads with only one lane for each direction keep a sufficient distance from the car in front so that an overtaking vehicle may pull in?

2.2.07-002.asw_pretext: Answer: All motor vehicles with a permissible total mass of up to
2.2.07-002.info: Within built-up areas – except on motorways – motorists driving vehicles with a maximum permissible mass of up to 3.5 t may freely choose which lane to use if multiple lanes in the same direction exist.
2.2.07-002.text: Which motor vehicles may freely choose their lane inside built-up areas?

2.2.09-001.asw_2: On clearways for motor vehicles only
2.2.09-001.info: Turning is prohibited on motorways and highways.

2.2.12-001.asw_1: Outside parking areas on autobahns and clearways for motor vehicles only
2.2.12-001.info: Stopping is not permitted in the area of sharp curves as well as on motorways and highways. In both cases, there is an increased risk of accidents.

2.2.12-003.asw_1: On narrow roadways opposite driveway entrances and exits
2.2.12-003.info: Parking is not permitted in front of property entrances and exits as well as on narrow lanes opposite property entrances and exits. The parked vehicle would be too big of an obstacle there. Anyone driving a vehicle is not permitted to stop at taxi stands, except for taxis providing for the carriage of passengers. You have to continue driving and find another parking possibility.

2.2.12-102.info: Anyone driving a vehicle may not park on sidewalks with vehicles with a maximum permissible mass exceeding 2.8 tonnes. Additional signs can additionally restrict the parking permit by, for example, limiting the parking time and prescribing the use of a parking notice.
2.2.12-102.text: Up to which permissible total mass may motor vehicles be parked on specially designated footpaths?

2.2.12-104.info: Anyone driving a vehicle must keep a minimum distance of 10 m in front of a traffic light in order to prevent the vehicle concealing the traffic light. The same also applies to the signs "Give priority to rail transport", "Give right of way" and "Stop! Give right of way!
2.2.12-104.text: What is the minimum distance a vehicle must leave clear in front of traffic lights if the traffic lights would be concealed by the vehicle?

2.2.12-105.asw_2: In wholly residential areas, on specially designated parking spaces
2.2.12-105.asw_3: In special areas reserved for recreation purposes, on sufficiently wide roads
2.2.12-105.info: Within built-up areas, motor vehicle trailers with a permissible total mass of more than 2 t are not permitted to park in 1. pure and general residential areas, 2. special recreational areas, 3. spa areas and 4. clinic areas between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m. hours or on Sundays and public holidays. This does not apply to appropriately marked parking spaces or to the parking of regular buses at terminal stops. Parking in industrial areas is also permitted.
2.2.12-105.text: Where are you allowed to park a trailer with a permissible total mass exceeding 2 t in built-up areas regularly on sundays and public holidays and between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m.?

2.2.12-106.asw_1: - may not be parked for more than 2 weeks on public roads
2.2.12-106.asw_2: - may be parked for more than 2 weeks on specially designated parking spaces
2.2.12-106.asw_3: - may be parked for an unlimited period of time on adequate hard shoulders
2.2.12-106.info: Parking time may be limited depending on the parking space. Trailers without a towing vehicle may not be parked for more than two weeks. This does not apply to appropriately marked parking spaces.
2.2.12-106.text: What must you remember when parking a trailer without a truck?

2.2.13-001.info: If a parking meter or a parking ticket machine is not functioning, parking may only be carried out up to the specified maximum parking duration. In this case, the parking disc must be used. A parking disc should be used if the traffic sign so requires.
